"No problem. Just be back by six," she said, returning her attention to the papers on her desk.

Jack nodded and made his way into the exhibit halls, where he was greeted by the familiar sights and sounds of the museum. He walked past a massive Egyptian statue, marveling at the intricate carvings and smooth, polished stone. As he continued on, his eyes wandered over to a painting of a majestic horse galloping through a lush green field. The brushstrokes were so delicate that it almost looked as if the horse could jump out of the canvas and run free. Jack couldn't help but smile at the sight.

He then turned into a long corridor filled with suits of armor, each one looking as though it had come straight out of a fairy tale. Jack paused in front of a particularly imposing set of armor, imagining himself as a knight in shining armor, riding off into the sunset on a quest for adventure.

A voice interrupted his daydreaming. "Jack, is that you?" It was one of his mother's colleagues, a woman he vaguely recognized from the restoration department. "Hi, it's Wendy. How's your summer going?"

Jack mumbled a greeting and quickly made his way down the corridor, feeling self-conscious under Wendy's gaze. He could never quite find the right words to say around her.

As he turned a corner, Jack suddenly remembered a time when he had visited the museum with his parents when he was much younger. They had walked through these same halls, his father lifting him up to get a better view of the paintings, his mother pointing out details he would have otherwise missed. Jack's father had died not long after that visit, and the memory filled him with a bittersweet longing.

He shook his head, pushing the memory away. Jack turned his attention back to the museum, letting the sights and sounds wash over him. He was content to spend hours wandering through the halls, lost in thought and wonder.
